moves.1. e4: This amateur starts with a basic opening.
moves.1... e5: Blackburne tries nothing esoteric, going with the Classical response.
moves.2. Nf3: The best second move available in this position.
moves.3. Bc4: The "Quiet Game" -- but not this time.
moves.3... Nd4: Now the sparks begin to fly.
moves.4... Qg5: Blackburne attacks the unprotected Knight and menaces the weak K-side with his Q.
moves.5. Nxf7: A seemingly winning move, as the protected Knight forks Blackburne's Q and R.
moves.5... Qxg2: Blackburne retaliates by attacking the White KR. If 6 NxR, 6...QxR ch followed by 7... QxKP ch equalizes the material and gives Blackburne the initiative. Furthermore, White's Knight at R8 would be in danger of being trapped.
moves.6. Rf1: White hastily moves his Rook out of danger. However, he has cut off a flight-square for his King in doing so.
moves.6... Qxe4+: Decisive. 7 Q-K2 would be answered by 7... NxQ, with a winning advantage in material. So White plays instead...
